2.54.text:
DANIEL ROTHSCHILD: Thank you all for joining
us for what is sure to be an interesting event.

17.13.text:
The latest in our Conversations with Tyler
series with our special guest today, Professor

22.15.text:
Jeffrey Sachs from Columbia University.
The Mercatus Center is the world’s premier

28.02.text:
university-based resource for market-oriented
ideas. Our mission at the Mercatus Center

32.93.text:
is to bridge the gap between academic research
and real-world public policy questions in

38.08.text:
Washington, states, and local governments,
and indeed around the world.

41.73.text:
Today’s event is in aid of that. The Conversations
with Tyler series is all about bringing together

48.29.text:
world-class thought leaders who are thinking
big thoughts about important ideas for conversations

53.77.text:
with the general director of the Mercatus
Center.

55.62.text:
With that, it’s my pleasure to introduce
Tyler Cowen. Tyler is a Holbert L. Harris

61.35.text:
Chair in Economics at George Mason University.
He also, along with Alex Tabarrok, is a coblogger

66.75.text:
at marginalrevolution.com, one of the country’s
premier econ blogs, and with Alex, is the

74.61.text:
cocreator of Marginal Revolution University,
an innovative online platform for learning

79.42.text:
about and teaching economics.
For those of you who are readers of Marginal

83.42.text:
Revolution, as you already know, Tyler’s
interests are many and varied—which makes

87.59.text:
him the perfect host for this series. I don’t
know where he and Professor Sachs are going

92.30.text:
to go in their conversation today, but I’m
sure it’s going to be challenging. It’s

96.52.text:
going to be interesting. Above all, it’s
going to be smart.

99.98.text:
Again, on behalf of the Mercatus Center, thank
you all for joining us today. Please join

104.30.text:
me in welcoming Tyler Cowen and Jeffrey Sachs.
[applause]

113.01.text:
TYLER COWEN: I introduce Jeff Sachs; that’s
easy. Jeff is one of the world’s best, most

124.43.text:
famous, and most influential economists. There’s
more I could say, but let’s start with that.

130.38.text:
The purpose of these series is to have conversations
that you don’t find other places on YouTube,

135.39.text:
and to ask probing questions and have a far-ranging
dialogue. What I’d like to do is kind of

141.41.text:
overview of Jeff’s career and thought and
try and see how it all hangs together, how

146.54.text:
the different pieces relate to each other.
What I’d like to do is start with some of

150.65.text:
the early pieces, from the ’80s and 1990s.
Then we’ll work our way up to the present.

155.89.text:
The first question, Jeff, and we’ll treat
this as a dialogue. Some of your best-cited

159.88.text:
work has been on the natural resource curse:
the idea that economies, when they have natural

165.76.text:
resources—such as oil—that can harm their
prospects for growth rather than helping them.

170.45.text:
Now we’re in 2015. How do you see this issue
today? Do you think that has changed in any

176.44.text:
way since the first thesis you wrote?
JEFFREY SACHS: First, let me say thank you

181.77.text:
for having me. I’m really looking forward
to our discussion.

187.88.text:
About 25 years ago, I started looking more
and more at my own work and how economic structure,

194.67.text:
geography, resource base, and so forth affected
development. I’ve been on a learning curve

202.91.text:
since then. One of the early works that I
engaged in at that point with Andrew Warner

210.62.text:
and others was looking at this question of
how resource wealth, resource dependence one

217.92.text:
could say, affected development.
We found back in the 1990s, looking for the

224.17.text:
preceding 25 years or so, that the oil-rich
countries had grown less rapidly, controlling

232.54.text:
for seemingly other factors that would be
relevant. We started to speculate about that.

238.87.text:
There’s now a huge literature from many
different points of view: politics, pure economics,

247.26.text:
and so forth. It’s a pretty rich subject
and not so simple to summarize. There really

262.01.text:
is a resource curse for a lot of resource-rich
countries.

266.55.text:
At this point, looking back, I would put more
weight on the political economy aspects probably

275.98.text:
than the pure, market-driven “Dutch disease”
aspects which I talked about a quarter century

283.63.text:
ago. The idea at the time was that if you
have resource wealth that pulls you away from

291.12.text:
more labor-intensive and technology-intensive
industries. You don’t learn as much. You

298.85.text:
don’t develop as much endogenous growth.
Now I would say if you have resource wealth,

305.03.text:
one problem is you’re likely to be invaded.
You have more vulnerability to geopolitics

311.66.text:
as well as to internal politics to mess things
up.

315.63.text:
TYLER COWEN: Is this a habit you can kick
or is it path dependence? The price of oil

320.54.text:
now is quite low. Do you think those countries
that have a lot of oil, now they’re going

325.46.text:
to be better off because they’ll be put
on this new development path, or is it somehow

329.03.text:
too late, that they’re stuck with the bad
institutions?

331.73.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: First, one of the things that
I’ve tried to emphasize and that I’ve

338.98.text:
learned over time is it’s always pretty
complicated. There are resource-rich countries

344.81.text:
that do very well, thank you. There are resource-rich
countries that have fallen apart a long time

350.51.text:
ago and never gotten out of the mess. Any
generalization is fraught with problems.

357.88.text:
Norway will do well, whether the oil price
is high or low. On the other hand, last time

367.83.text:
the world oil price was persistently low,
the Soviet Union collapsed. Russia was near

376.46.text:
hyperinflation. Different countries under
different conditions will adjust to these

386.07.text:
shocks. Resource-rich Norway, Australia, Canada—I
wouldn’t worry too much about them.

394.05.text:
Their currencies will weaken. They will find
other things to do, whereas some of the very

402.87.text:
vulnerable countries that have never been
able to kick the habit of dependence, like

410.93.text:
Venezuela, will probably go into a deeper
crisis. The Middle East has been in flames

417.23.text:
now for years. I don’t see any easy way
out there, either.

420.78.text:
TYLER COWEN: Here’s the tension I’m trying
to figure out. It relates to a number of issues

425.66.text:
in your thought. You’ve written some very
interesting pieces lately about how the role

430.11.text:
of institutions is overrated in predicting
growth, but institutions seem to play a key

435.49.text:
role in making the resource theory stick.
As you say, Norway has done fine. The US in

441.93.text:
earlier times did fine with a lot of natural
resources.

444.59.text:
Does thinking about resources lead you back
to seeing institutions as important in some

450.29.text:
new and different way or are you still basically
skeptical about institutions mattering at

454.81.text:
all and wanting to look most of all to geography?
Do you see what I’m getting at?

459.19.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Of course, but again, I’ll
say it repeatedly, I’ve never said institutions

466.15.text:
don’t matter. I’ve said institutions aren’t
the only thing. I find often that people take

477.18.text:
an idea and carry it to an extreme.
This “institution matters” idea is one

485.24.text:
of those that I’ve found taken to extremes
by causing a kind of geographic blindness,

493.13.text:
if I could say it. Geography obviously matters
a lot. Resource base matters a lot. Institutions

498.71.text:
matter a lot. The world’s complex. We’re
dealing with complex systems.

503.11.text:
It’s not surprising that different things
matter at different times and different places.

508.20.text:
Of course, institutions make a difference.
The art of good economics, in my view, is

512.89.text:
trying to figure out what’s important, where,
when, and in which context.

516.72.text:
TYLER COWEN: Here’s a claim you’ve made.
It’s very striking. It’s one of the most

521.51.text:
important claims in development economics.
Personally, I think it’s true.

525.46.text:
When you reviewed Acemoglu and Robinson, you
said, “If we go to the year 1960, even knowing

530.85.text:
who the winners and losers have been, much
less forget about forecasting, it’s very

535.98.text:
hard to come up with a metric of institutions
that predicts which countries end up doing

541.02.text:
well and which countries end up doing poorly.”
When I read that, I tend to think somehow

547.51.text:
we’re mismeasuring institutional quality.
We really need a better measure of institutions,

552.58.text:
which we don’t have yet. Institutions will
someday matter again, but I’m looking for

557.64.text:
this in vain.
Where does your thought stand on this now?

560.35.text:
Do you actually think there’s some deeper
understanding of institutions that will rescue

564.90.text:
this proposition? When you throw out North
Korea and some other crazy countries, institutions

570.58.text:
don’t really have the predictive power for
growth.

573.11.text:
What are your thoughts on this, given that
in the across-country regressions, they can

577.54.text:
do so poorly within the set of semireasonable
countries?

580.80.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Acemoglu and Robinson’s book
Why Nations Fail was one of my least favorite

587.27.text:
books. I think it is just a bad book, because
it takes one thought and tries to drive it

595.90.text:
as the only explanation of history. That’s
not a good approach in my view to history,

604.09.text:
which is a very interesting, complex tableau.
They missed one fundamental point right from

612.84.text:
the start, which is that when you look at
development, there are at least two fundamental

619.01.text:
drivers, not just one. The one that they talk
about is innovation, and innovation as being

626.84.text:
a fundamental driver of growth. There’s
a lot of truth to that in the history of the

632.20.text:
world.
But there’s a second fundamental aspect

636.40.text:
when we look out in the world and say, “Who’s
doing well? Who’s doing badly? Why?” and

641.74.text:
so forth. That’s what is sometimes called
“catching up.” The phenomenon of catching

645.95.text:
up is very different from the phenomenon of
forging ahead at the front of the technology

654.58.text:
horizon.
When you take that simple distinction, it

661.55.text:
helps to explain a lot of the post-1960 question
that you’re asking. The most successful

668.18.text:
countries in the world in the last 50 years
have been basically the East Asian economies

675.12.text:
and Southeast Asian economies.
Very rarely do they look like the textbook

682.61.text:
model of Acemoglu and Robinson of the free
market economy and so forth. In fact, the

693.41.text:
People’s Republic of China they characterize
as just—that’s an anomaly that is going

699.02.text:
to collapse in the future so we don’t have
to explain it now.

702.95.text:
I think that’s a huge mistake and a misunderstanding
of the basics. China’s in a catching-up

707.61.text:
mode. The institutions of catching up are
quite different from the institutions of being

713.63.text:
the technology leader, for example. Just understanding
that would give them a little more clarity

720.04.text:
about institutions, per se.
TYLER COWEN: And corruption, over- or underrated

724.36.text:
as a driver of growth?
JEFFREY SACHS: It depends. Some places are

729.08.text:
so corrupt you first wouldn’t want to step
foot in them and I’ve had the experience

736.71.text:
repeatedly when I’m talking to a head of
state or a finance minister and I watch their

745.68.text:
eyes glaze over and realize they’re not
interested in what you’re talking about.

751.89.text:
They’re in a different game. Those places
can be driven absolutely into the ground by

759.84.text:
corruption.
Other places have been corrupt for a long

765.19.text:
time—I’m thinking of New York, Washington,
Lagos, Beijing, and other places—and you

776.35.text:
get a lot of economic progress. In that sense,
there is no purity in the world. I’m not

784.71.text:
a fan of corruption for a lot of reasons that
have started with the ethics.

788.61.text:
TYLER COWEN: China’s massively corrupt and
it’s growing at high rates, right?

793.05.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: China has a lot of corruption.
The first person to say it is President Xi.

800.23.text:
The US has a huge amount of corruption and
it has done reasonably well over the last

808.81.text:
200 years.
TYLER COWEN: Let me now ask you a question

811.67.text:
to challenge the audience, and we’re going
to turn to Paul Rosenstein-Rodan, who’s

815.92.text:
somewhat of a forgotten figure. But I think
still an important figure at George Mason,

820.42.text:
and maybe for you too.
As you know, Rosenstein-Rodan was a development

824.76.text:
economist. He was one of the pioneers of the
notion of the big push of an extended move

830.18.text:
forward on many fronts, all at the same time.
But when you look at the early years of his

835.08.text:
thought, he studied with Mises. He worked
with Hayek. He was an Austrian. He was a subjectivist,

841.66.text:
methodological individualist, and he made
some kind of theoretical shift in his mind.

847.42.text:
What is it that you think that Paul Rosenstein-Rodan
saw, and presumably you think you see it as

853.65.text:
well, that the people today who are still
Austrians at the theoretical level, what is

859.19.text:
it that Rosenstein-Rodan saw that allowed
him to make that shift or induced him to make

865.16.text:
that shift at the most basic conceptual level?
JEFFREY SACHS: He was writing during and at

871.33.text:
the end of World War II, when he was saying,
“How are we going to get out of this mess?

875.07.text:
There are so many pieces that have to be put
together. We have to get infrastructure built

879.37.text:
again. We have to get basic markets operating.
There are a lot of interconnected pieces,

887.65.text:
and so we’re going to have to move on a
lot of fronts.” He was facing a historical

891.32.text:
situation.
I would say that his idea—I’d go back

898.35.text:
even . . . actually, it’s not back. It was
almost contemporaneous with him. Alexander

903.42.text:
Gerschenkron, who was a very clever economic
historian at Harvard. I came as a student

914.54.text:
just as he was retiring. He was a great mid-century,
mid-20th century economic historian.

923.98.text:
He observed that what countries do for development
depends on how they stand in relation to the

932.91.text:
leader, and this is a point I was making earlier,
which is that catching up is a fundamental

940.48.text:
phenomenon in development.
There’s a difference of growth, which we

946.16.text:
study as an economy, how does it grow? From
the question of catching up, which is a question

954.09.text:
for a country that is situated with weak technology,
weak infrastructure, weak training, and so

961.61.text:
forth. In the face of advanced economies,
what should they do?

966.69.text:
Now that’s been a question that’s been
asked for at least 224 years, since Alexander

976.75.text:
Hamilton sent his letter to the congress on
manufacturing in the United States. Because

981.57.text:
he said we have to catch up with Britain.
Then Friedrich List said, “We have to catch

986.24.text:
up with Britain.” Economic reformers from
basically Hamilton on in countries that were

997.43.text:
lagging behind the lead said, “What do we
do to catch up?”

1001.13.text:
Now you can carry this too far because the
insane version of this, and the unbelievably

1007.44.text:
destructive version of this, was Lenin and
Stalin. We have to do anything at no matter

1012.03.text:
what cost of life to catch up, or Mao in the
Great Leap Forward, which is insanity and

1019.22.text:
cruelty.
But, on the other hand, the idea that you

1022.79.text:
do different things to catch up by accelerating
the process or by making the big push in a

1030.13.text:
variety of ways has been shown time and again
to have a lot of merit. It’s a balance,

1037.67.text:
once more. The first countries to develop,
Britain and the United States . . . Take the

1042.57.text:
US. We’ve achieved almost continuous 1.8
percent per year per capita growth for the

1049.31.text:
last 200 years. Not bad, if you do it for
200 years.

1054.43.text:
But if you’re an impoverished country today
and you say, “What’s our aim? 1.8 percent

1059.21.text:
growth?” No, our aim is 10 percent growth,
because we really need to catch up. It turned

1066.48.text:
out, because of that catching-up phenomenon,
you can make a very, very rapid advance in

1073.42.text:
a way unthinkable for a country in front.
But how do you make that advance? Through

1080.59.text:
pure government just stepping back and letting
things happen? No. Through a concerted policy

1088.45.text:
to close gaps. That’s the difference.
TYLER COWEN: I’ve been reviewing your work,

1093.83.text:
including these books, and a stack of papers
here, which is a small fraction of what you’ve

1100.05.text:
written. I believe they all have your name
on them. What I try to do with thinkers sometimes

1105.56.text:
is boil down what they’ve been writing to
the smallest number of dimensions possible.

1110.44.text:
If you’ll bear with me for a moment, I’m
going to try to do that with you, and then

1114.26.text:
you tell me where I’m off, or what you would
add to that. Reviewing all the things you’ve

1119.61.text:
written . . .
JEFFREY SACHS: You probably know more about

1121.21.text:
me than I do, so let’s see how it goes.
[laughter]

1124.17.text:
TYLER COWEN: Maybe. But there are two phrases
that strike me again and again. One is when

1128.21.text:
you mention your wife, Sonia, and talk about
differential diagnostics. The other is what

1133.84.text:
you call the epoch of the Anthropocene, which
you could think of as the time when human

1139.56.text:
beings are in the world in an active way.
When we start with primitive society, everything

1146.42.text:
is determined by geography and resources.
Economic development, in a sense, is an ongoing

1153.14.text:
process where human beings impose their will
and their reason on the world in a kind of

1160.83.text:
planning or voluntaristic fashion.
Then there’s a belief that first this needs

1166.50.text:
to be done in a differential way. Not the
same recipe everywhere. But a belief in the

1172.50.text:
power of human reason to perform these differential
diagnostics to turn this era when humans are

1178.65.text:
on the earth into a time when we’re no longer
ruled by resources and geography and the prevalence

1184.43.text:
of malaria. But brought into an era where
human reason is in some sense running the

1189.37.text:
show.
If I had to boil down my reread of you into

1193.48.text:
a very short bulletin, that’s what I would
say. Now do you agree with that, how would

1198.89.text:
you change it, and what would you add to that?
JEFFREY SACHS: That’s pretty good, first

1202.99.text:
of all. I would subscribe to that summary.
I should explain this idea of clinical economics,

1213.05.text:
as I’ve called it, or differential diagnosis.
When you’re married to a pediatrician, as

1218.67.text:
I have been for 35 wonderful years, you get
up in the middle of the night a lot when patients

1226.05.text:
call with a very sick child.
I’ve listened to my wife take an oral history

1230.96.text:
a thousand—thousands of times, perhaps.
It’s a wonderful art, first of all, because

1243.68.text:
a mother calls with a crisis of a baby or
a young child—usually a high fever. The

1252.02.text:
first thing that is important to know is that
there are a thousand possible etiologies of

1258.89.text:
that fever. My wife doesn’t say institutions.
She says . . .

1267.82.text:
hear your problem. Oh, you’re in a desert,
you’re here, you’re this . . .” No,

1277.08.text:
when it comes to the child, it could be something
as normal as a common cold or a something

1285.21.text:
as devastating as meningitis.
The purpose of a differential diagnosis is

1293.19.text:
two things. First, it is of course to try
to get to the core reasons so that you can

1303.23.text:
make a proper prescription based on a proper
diagnosis. Second, it’s done in a way that

1310.50.text:
you’re minimizing serious risk.
The first question always that my wife asks

1317.32.text:
is, “Is the baby’s neck stiff, or do you
notice that?” Because that’s one of the

1322.40.text:
symptoms of meningitis. If the mother answers
that way, the next point is “I’ll meet

1332.43.text:
you at the emergency room. Don’t stop. Just
go.” Because it could be something that

1337.32.text:
is fulminant and life-threatening immediately.
If it’s not that, then it can go on for

1342.63.text:
an hour.
But by the way, it’s not just an hour of

1346.28.text:
questions. It’s an hour of sequenced questions
down a decision tree, and it’s fascinating

1350.98.text:
to watch. I wish as economists we had those
basic skills inbred. I certainly didn’t

1357.83.text:
learn them, and it took me a long time of
seeing lots of “patients” to see that

1363.45.text:
one needs that same kind of approach.
That’s what I mean by differential diagnosis.

1369.64.text:
Why it’s so annoying to me, the one explanation
fits all viewpoints. Because now I’ve seen

1377.26.text:
a lot of places, a lot of crises, a lot of
challenges. One of the things that I discovered

1385.02.text:
was how poor our profession is at times in
having that sense that the problem that you

1395.23.text:
saw over there is not the same as the problem
that you’re seeing here.

1399.95.text:
TYLER COWEN: Let me push on this a bit and
see if you can convert me into being more

1405.00.text:
of a Sachsian. One of my worries is that the
doctors are not actually in charge. It may

1410.53.text:
be the lawyers, which is . . . We’re in
a law school, but still, if I may say, in

1414.08.text:
some ways a step down.
To some extent you have people voting on the

1419.34.text:
baby, not all of whom even know who the baby
is or what the baby’s symptoms are. The

1426.02.text:
differential diagnostics may exist in a kind
of platonic realm, but you are more optimistic

1432.10.text:
about them than I am.
What would you tell me to address my skepticism

1437.38.text:
and make me more of a Sachsian, given that
I have this reluctance to embrace your view

1442.58.text:
the way you hold it?
JEFFREY SACHS: I think I get what you’re

1446.86.text:
driving at and I do have a fundamental view
of at least how I want to proceed professionally.

1455.79.text:
But it’s also based a bit on a theory of
change.

1461.39.text:
TYLER COWEN: Tell us the theory.
JEFFREY SACHS: I believe that knowledge matters

1467.02.text:
and that the more clarity, the more evidence,
the more appropriate an analysis, the more

1481.37.text:
likely we can find a good outcome to things.
Many people are cynical. I tend not to be.

1493.84.text:
I’m sometimes accused of being gullible
as a result, or being too soft in the face

1498.58.text:
of whatever. But I believe that there’s
a way to reach an agreement, typically, among

1510.21.text:
pretty conflictual and often pretty antagonistic
actors.

1515.90.text:
I tend to believe there’s a way out of a
crisis, and I tend to believe that a lot of

1520.57.text:
what poses as either pure zero-sum struggle
or harsh ideological conflict is often resolvable

1535.82.text:
by good, clear ideas, or good, clear evidence,
or a good, clear game plan.

1540.54.text:
TYLER COWEN: So you’re very optimistic about
the power of human reason?

1544.25.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: I believe that’s where we
should put our bets.

1547.13.text:
TYLER COWEN: That’s a different claim. See,
I believe we should put our bets on human

1551.08.text:
reason. It’s all we have. But I’m not
necessarily that . . .

1554.18.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Then we don’t have to even
disagree, because we’re going to act the

1557.36.text:
same way.
TYLER COWEN: Let me mention this book. Reading

1560.17.text:
this book, it really cleared up for me, I
think, a lot of the things you believe. It’s

1564.24.text:
called To Move the World: JFK’s Quest for
Peace. It came out last year. It’s received

1569.35.text:
attention, but less so from economists, for
obvious reasons.

1572.75.text:
It’s a book about leaders sitting down and
just doing something and basically getting

1578.30.text:
it right. Is that fair to say? Solving—more
or less solving the Cuban Missile Crisis,

1583.45.text:
defusing tensions, avoiding nuclear war, right?
JEFFREY SACHS: It’s a book, yes, of this

1591.14.text:
remarkable last year of Kennedy’s life,
which included the Cuban Missile Crisis and

1598.20.text:
then negotiating the partial nuclear test
ban treaty. Basically, I find it a story of

1609.47.text:
tremendous insight and very moving also. If
I could put it in pure conceptual jargon,

1618.35.text:
it’s a story of finding a way to the cooperative
outcome of a prisoner’s dilemma.

1625.24.text:
That’s, to my mind, a crucial structural
feature of our lives, which is that we face

1633.64.text:
constantly this challenge of finding agreement.
We face constantly the logic of defection,

1644.10.text:
as it’s called in the prisoner’s dilemma,
or the noncooperative outcome that’s worse

1649.16.text:
for everybody.
The question is what to do about that. The

1656.61.text:
cynics say, “Well, the world’s bound to
disagree.” The idealists say, “The world

1667.98.text:
will always agree, or we should always act
that way.” I find fascinating and compelling

1676.53.text:
the idea that we should try to find ways to
move to cooperation, knowing how fragile that

1685.61.text:
is.
TYLER COWEN: This story, it really fits your

1687.94.text:
model of change. That’s why, reading the
book, it was like a lightbulb went off in

1691.52.text:
my head.
JEFFREY SACHS: For me, it also went off in

1695.21.text:
my head as I learned more about this, which
is that Kennedy and Khrushchev stumbled into

1705.94.text:
nearly the end of the world in October of
1962, and Kennedy made his share of terrible

1715.28.text:
mistakes. Our USG, which I’m usually not
too much of a fan of, made its share of terrible

1723.37.text:
mistakes, whether it’s Bay of Pigs or other
things.

1727.26.text:
One by one, we stumbled—not to the desire
of either of these leaders—to the point

1735.65.text:
where we were within the hair’s breadth
of total annihilation. So many stupid things

1743.53.text:
happen in this world, as almost happened again.
Some pilot gets lost over Alaska and flies

1749.26.text:
over the Soviet Union, or Russian local commanders
in Cuba have the power to fire nuclear weapons.

1758.16.text:
We’re so close to the edge.
The Cuban missile crisis is defused I think

1765.42.text:
with real humanity by Kennedy, and by Khrushchev.
Then they both basically reached the intuition,

1778.25.text:
“This is insane, the way we’re acting.
This is crazy.” They find a way to reach

1784.96.text:
an agreement next year.
It’s an agreement in which typically the

1791.01.text:
right on both sides that they face, or the
hard-liners, the nationalists on both sides,

1795.98.text:
say, “You can’t agree with each other!”
and they find a way to reach an agreement.

1800.57.text:
So to me, it is a paradigm of how we can stay
alive in this world and actually get somewhere.

1806.75.text:
TYLER COWEN: If I thought more problems were

1811.64.text:
numbers of players, didn’t have clear channels

but were more of just a big, messy splat.
Should I then be more pessimistic about differential

1824.74.text:
diagnostics? Or do you think that as a model
of social change still is going to hold?

1829.27.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: For me, the biggest, most complicated

1835.84.text:
you’re describing is climate change. Which
in my now 43 years of thinking about economics,

1847.37.text:
so it’s a long time, is the most complicated
mess that I can imagine. It’s got every

1854.95.text:

It’s global, it’s long-term, it’s uncertain.

1862.96.text:
It’s got vested interests, it’s got hugely

1870.38.text:
with it as a problem.
Yet a lot of people do say, “Eh, there’s

1881.24.text:
no chance. You can’t really do much.”
If you asked me, “Where do I stand?” I

1887.25.text:
say, “We can solve this problem. There is

1894.53.text:
it at this stage as staying below the two-degree
Celsius warming which governments have agreed,

1901.08.text:
but not honored, as an upper limit of warming.
I’m taking an approach of how I think I

1908.27.text:
can contribute to that in a very particular
way. That way is by helping to define more

1915.53.text:
clearly what that path involves and managing
a 15-country project for the UN on defining

1926.14.text:
pathways that satisfy that.
To my mind that reflects at least my style

1933.25.text:
of what I believe is the way to do this, which
is to say, “Well, what does a solution look

1940.81.text:
like?” It comes back to what [Thomas] Schelling
called a focal point for bargaining. Here’s

1946.12.text:
where we could go.
I think that is very important to identify

1952.33.text:
in messy situations. Here’s where we can
get to. Don’t you see, for all of us, that’s

1959.24.text:
an improvement, that’s better than the mess
that we’re on? I believe if you say that

1966.42.text:
enough and you’re clear enough about it,

1970.67.text:
Or, not really, but you’ll have the best

1977.67.text:
of problem-solving that we should try to use

1987.64.text:
so-called, which is that there is no magic

the solution. We have to actually agree on

It’s been a success. If I made the following

Jeffrey Sachs, have done more for economic

Poland than almost any other economist alive

2026.50.text:
[laughter]
JEFFREY SACHS: I’d say that things I recommended

were—that was good advice I gave back then.

2039.48.text:
very remarkable period of my life and a very

2048.05.text:
these periods when you’re just struck at

2058.56.text:
to find a way out of that.
Just to tie that strategy in with how I’m

2069.15.text:
explaining my general approach, actually,

2076.82.text:
rapid change of economic institutions, structure,

2087.46.text:
the internal dynamics of what was happening

2093.36.text:
But the basic idea of course was not mine

2102.34.text:
moment, and the basic idea was also Solidarity
movement’s idea, and here’s what I mean.

2109.50.text:
I was asked at one point, “Write a plan.”
It was for me an unbelievable moment which

2118.85.text:
I remember as vividly as anything I remember.
Because I said, “I’ll send this to you

2124.17.text:
in a couple weeks.” It was one of Lech Wałęsa’s
top advisors who said, “I need it tomorrow

2129.83.text:
morning.”

2136.09.text:
of four years of Harvard all-nighters. So

2141.78.text:
for transforming Poland from a communist,

2147.83.text:
If anyone’s interested, I’ll send you
the document, which I recovered from a box

2153.55.text:
sometime a few years ago.
What he told me was, he said, “I don’t

2161.45.text:
care what you put. You have to explain it,

2167.03.text:
to Europe.” The message was like giving

2182.25.text:

At the time it was what I believed in. But

2193.39.text:
We want to be a normal country in Europe.

2198.16.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: And they are now, completely.
It’s totally normal. As one of the greatest

2203.34.text:
leaders of our time in human rights, Adam

2208.41.text:
went from the great drama of revolution to

But the point I want to make, Tyler, is that

2218.18.text:
else fits, once you have an idea of that compelling

2229.68.text:

2233.58.text:
Take away everything that doesn’t look like

2236.95.text:
TYLER COWEN: Then Russia, which I blame only
on the Russians, by the way. But they never

had a comparable endpoint in mind. Is that
fair to say?

2244.95.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: I think there are two things.
I blame a lot of it on Dick Cheney, so not

2250.25.text:
just on Russia. Russia itself, by virtue of
Russia, 11 time zones of the Eurasian land

2261.14.text:
mass, does not have a fixed focal point, and

2268.05.text:
civilization, the Third Rome, and half of
Russian history is being part of Europe and

2274.41.text:
being part of European civilization. They’ve
never settled that question until now.

2279.73.text:
But the other difference which I found—(I
didn’t understand it then, almost at all,

2285.12.text:
by the way. It took me 20 years to understand
it, actually.)—was how weird it was that

2295.81.text:
in 1989, and this is geopolitics, which I

In 1989, I made recommendations for Poland.
I said several unusual things, like “Don’t

2314.52.text:
pay your debts, get debt cancellation. You
need emergency, a billion dollars on this

2322.37.text:
date,” and so forth. Everything I recommended

2329.61.text:
support.

2333.88.text:
by Gorbachev and then by Yeltsin to help them,
because they saw what was happening in Poland.

2338.83.text:
They liked that. They wanted something similar.
So I said exactly the same things, and the

2344.42.text:
US government kept saying, “No, no way,
no way.” I kept saying, “But that kept

2350.21.text:
working there.”
I didn’t understand it in some deep sense

2355.39.text:
for a long, long time, how weird this was.
I knew it wasn’t the difference of economic

2361.92.text:
advice. I understand what a financial crisis
is.

2364.79.text:
TYLER COWEN: Culturally weird, you mean.
JEFFREY SACHS: No, how weird it was in the

2368.82.text:
historical moment that things that had worked
extremely well, had shown themselves, where

2374.64.text:
I had had Brent Scowcroft and Bob Dole and

2380.73.text:
just no support from Washington. The IMF saying,
“We’re not going to do this.” I said,

2387.12.text:
“But, Richard Urban, you did that two years
ago in Poland.” “We’re not going to

2392.00.text:
do it.” “Why?” Flat.
OK. What’s the lesson of this? Quite important,

2398.99.text:
actually. It’s a little bit off-topic, but
very important. We didn’t want to help Russia

2407.17.text:
in 1991. We wanted our unipolar world. I didn’t
know that at the time. For me, I wanted to

2414.49.text:
help Russia. This is a chance for freedom,
democracy, market economy, normalcy. Yeltsin

2419.83.text:
defined, he said December 11, when I met him
the first time, 1991, “We want to be a normal

2428.75.text:
country.” I said, “I will help you, Mr.
President.”

2433.44.text:
We didn’t want that in this country. What
I didn’t understand was everything I said

2438.84.text:
about Poland was immediately accepted because
it was good advice and because Poland was

2445.82.text:
going to be a bulwark of NATO. Everything
I said about Russia didn’t matter whether

2450.75.text:
it was good advice or not. Russia was on the
other side.

2453.08.text:
TYLER COWEN: But China did it without us,
without American help for the most part. What

2458.49.text:
is it about Russia that meant Russia couldn’t
do it? The problem was not like a Khrushchev-Kennedy

2463.66.text:
dialog. But Russia must have failed in some
other way where China more or less did not.

2468.61.text:
What is that element?
JEFFREY SACHS: Many things. First of all,

2477.13.text:
Russia faced in 1991 an extremely acute financial
crisis. If you haven’t lived through a deep,

2489.82.text:
deep, deep financial crisis, it’s hard to
understand what it is.

2495.46.text:
Now we’ve lived through something mild like
that in 2008, which was frightening enough.

2500.49.text:
But I’ve now seen them many times and studied
them for my whole career. They’re very fulminant.

2508.70.text:
They’re like that meningitis epidemic. They
absolutely can rip a society apart before

2516.51.text:
you turn around.
Russia had that. It had that for all sorts

2520.86.text:
of reasons, but one was that the price of
oil had declined at $10 a barrel, and Gorbachev

2526.11.text:
had borrowed tens of billions of dollars from
1985 to 1991 and run out of money. They ran

2534.49.text:
out of reserves at the end of 1991. This was
a macro, macro crisis, and it was a very bad

2542.84.text:
one.
The same thing had happened in Poland in a

2547.62.text:
different time dimension, but by 1989, so
that’s why it called for debt cancellation,

2553.36.text:
a standstill on debt payments, an emergency
stabilization fund.

2557.09.text:
The first point is financial crisis is in
and of itself a distinct category of pathology.

2567.45.text:
Russia had it, China, thank goodness for them,
didn’t have it. Russia needed help on a

2573.66.text:
financial crisis. That’s number one.
By the time they got out of the financial

2580.80.text:
crisis, which was several years later, because
we completely stuck it to them in amazing

2589.01.text:
ways and allowed the crisis to be fulminant
for a number of years. The reformers were

2597.97.text:
gone, the corruption was completely out of
control.

2602.79.text:
I don’t want to exonerate the Russians for
the irresponsibility and so on and the lack

2608.68.text:
of good strategy. But often in a historical
context, to solve a problem you need both

2618.96.text:
sides operating. There are other serious differences,
very major differences that are worth just

2629.84.text:
mentioning. We could go into length. But there’s
a big difference of being a urban industrial,

2636.18.text:
broken, Soviet economy.
TYLER COWEN: Which was deindustrializing eventually

2641.94.text:
anyway.
JEFFREY SACHS: Which had so overgrown the

2646.69.text:
investor heavy industry, and it was in a lot
of collapse, versus being an agrarian, impoverished

2655.70.text:
country, as China was in 1978. The pathways
were bound to be very, very different. The

2664.28.text:
geography is different, by the way, because
China’s just filled with people who could

2668.65.text:
do low-cost labor right at the ports on the
east coast of China.

2674.75.text:
Whereas for Russia, it’s almost basically
a landlocked landmass that was running off

2685.33.text:
of petroleum which had collapsed in global
price, which had collapsed in the physical

2693.06.text:
facilities in the countryside, with collapsing

2700.57.text:
It just looked like a waste dump in 1991 when

2709.52.text:
airplanes at every airport just rusting away,

2718.95.text:
you turned. Cement melting away wherever you
turned. The place had just been a heavy industrial

2727.71.text:
machine for the military-industrial complex
for decades.

TYLER COWEN: Let’s do some quick question
and response. I’ll name some things. You

2735.38.text:
tell me if you think they’re underrated
or overrated.

2738.42.text:
Charter cities concept.
JEFFREY SACHS: I haven’t seen any result

2743.83.text:
of it.
TYLER COWEN: Are you hopeful? Powers of human

2746.95.text:
reason? Khrushchev-Kennedy, sit down?
JEFFREY SACHS: Look, cities are . . . If you’re

talking Paul Romer’s concept.
TYLER COWEN: Yes, among others.

2755.15.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: I think they’re . . . And

2765.61.text:
the idea of cities to say, “We should do
something different.” I’m not happy to

2770.35.text:
say, “We’re going to take an extraterritorial

be governed locally. It’s going to have

features that never struck me as politically

realistic.
TYLER COWEN: The Export-Import Bank. Overrated

2785.63.text:
or underrated?
JEFFREY SACHS: I’d vote for it.

TYLER COWEN: You’d vote to keep it?
JEFFREY SACHS: I’d vote to keep it.

TYLER COWEN: Even though it’s corporate
welfare?

2796.70.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Yeah, because it basically

2803.55.text:
things. I believe that in general, our international

2811.73.text:
financing international flows. I think we
need institutions to overcome the inherent

2819.62.text:
shortcomings of international finance.
TYLER COWEN: Anthropologists.

2823.94.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Anthropologists?
TYLER COWEN: They’re often critical of economists

2828.48.text:
and development. You’re an economist. In

2832.89.text:
the profession. A lot of anthropologists criticize

JEFFREY SACHS: First of all, I think that

2843.29.text:
anthropology in the form of getting a very

2852.80.text:

2861.77.text:
economics in the original, literal sense of

2868.46.text:
than we have.

2872.83.text:
in a world of 20th-century evolutionary psychology,

2882.79.text:
understanding. We need a new anthropology

2886.29.text:
TYLER COWEN: The economy of Mexico, overrated
or underrated?

2889.93.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: It’s probably accurately
rated, which is “Eh,” really strangely

2899.99.text:
underperforming for a long time, with a lot
of difficulty, but 100 million people living

in a kind of middle-income stasis and probably

so near to the United States.

2924.28.text:
as many problems as it’s created opportunities.

and war on drugs, for example, which has been

2938.34.text:
TYLER COWEN: If I said this: the core problem

informal sector. Productivity in the formal
sector is often remarkably high. Mexico will

become number three for auto exports. They’re

2952.92.text:

2958.25.text:
from the informal sector to the formal sector

2962.85.text:
That’s what we see. To accelerate that,
Mexico needs in some ways to deregulate. Would

2968.53.text:
you agree or disagree?
JEFFREY SACHS: I don’t know. Mexico is a

2976.50.text:
little bit, I would say, just stepping back,
a little bit of a mystery for me, why it hasn’t

2981.97.text:
done better in development.
TYLER COWEN: Let’s talk about Africa. Now

2985.79.text:
you must know Dani Rodrik’s work. He and
I, maybe you too, he’s worried about premature

2991.54.text:
deindustrialization. That in the old days,
countries like the US would have over a quarter

2996.34.text:
of their labor force working in manufacturing
with middle-class jobs, often be democratic,

3001.57.text:
and then they would deindustrialize.
The new wave of emerging economies, we’re

3005.99.text:
often seeing them deindustrialize at 10 to

3011.23.text:
It may be that service-sector jobs for cultural,
economic reasons, some reasons, don’t give

3017.07.text:
you the same kind of enduring, increasing

3021.86.text:
growth. So when it comes to Africa or other

3027.67.text:
premature deindustrialization?
JEFFREY SACHS: Not very much.

3030.81.text:
TYLER COWEN: Why not?
JEFFREY SACHS: I don’t think that there’s

3034.64.text:
any magic to manufacturing. What there is
crucially is a need for all developing countries

3042.05.text:
to export. You need to export because you
need to import technology. Manufacturing has

3048.24.text:
been a route to export earnings, to earning
a place in the world that allows you to import

3055.50.text:
the technology which 99.9 percent comes from
outside your country.

3060.67.text:
The question to ask for Africa is how is it
going to pay its way in the world? Not whether

3065.04.text:
it’s going to have manufacturing or not.
That’s why, by the way, import-substituting

3071.04.text:
manufacturing was no great help for countries

3079.33.text:
is export-oriented manufacturing. Maybe it’ll
be export-oriented services, mining, agribusiness,

3088.43.text:
and other things.

3091.88.text:
disadvantaged by having to catch up today
versus having to catch up 25 years net-net?”

3101.70.text:
I’d say better off now, because the basic
tools for catching up with the information

3110.07.text:
age are stronger now than before.
TYLER COWEN: But when you say mining, I worry

3115.52.text:
about your own resource curse. When you say

3121.08.text:
as we all know. But if you look at Indian

of a kind of feudal bastion, almost. Companies

3131.96.text:
almost like small private cities.

3136.94.text:
well for you. But it’s actually a very small

3142.51.text:
they have a head start there. If you think

3147.14.text:
be employed exporting services . . . Do you
think there’s an argument it could be more

3151.42.text:
than three or 4 percent?
JEFFREY SACHS: I think the question of how

3157.59.text:
any low-income country pays its way in the
world, as I said, is a real question. If it

3164.37.text:
weren’t for that question, there is no shortage
of identifiable jobs that Africa needs for

3173.62.text:
the coming two generations. It needs teachers
and it needs doctors and it needs construction

3180.00.text:
workers and it needs engineers and it needs
public administration and it needs everything,

3187.61.text:
because it’s coming from poor, rural, overwhelmingly
agriculture.

3192.96.text:
I’m not worried about the job root, but
what I am worried about is the balance of

3199.88.text:
payments basically, which is that like any
of us, we thrive if we can sell our services

3208.18.text:
somehow. That’s true at a country level
as it is at an individual level. If you are

3216.87.text:
in an environment where you have nothing to
sell, you may have a comparative advantage

3222.96.text:
but if you have nothing to sell, it doesn’t
matter. Everybody, every place has a comparative

3228.69.text:
advantage but it doesn’t necessarily make
you prosperous.

3232.24.text:
I worry very much about places like Chad,
Niger, Central African Republic, Mali because

3241.98.text:
they’re landlocked, they are in incredibly
difficult physical geographic conditions,

3252.11.text:
very dry, drying most likely, warming, massive
disease burden, most of them with no easy

3261.60.text:
natural resource base, too far from ports
to do any kind of assembly operations. It’s

3271.31.text:
a stepping stone for development.
TYLER COWEN: Geography again.

3275.94.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Just extraordinarily difficult.
It’s why I also worry about Africa’s demographic

3282.03.text:
trends because obviously I think a lot about
the difficulties of development. You’re

3287.32.text:
mentioning some, but as hard as it is for
Africa now with one billion in sub-Saharan

3296.36.text:
Africa, Africa’s going to have two billion
people before the middle of the century on

3301.86.text:
the trajectory. It’s going to have around
four billion people on the so-called medium

3307.31.text:
variant fertility trajectory that the UN population
division puts forward.

3316.66.text:
I find sustainable development in Africa in
those terms not feasible. I couldn’t answer

3323.06.text:
that question, what is a viable path. When
you think about the problems of development

3331.64.text:
in very poor, difficult conditions as much
of sub-Saharan Africa has right now, the best

3341.98.text:
thing going forward is this tremendous room
for catching up.

3347.92.text:
That means a lot of leapfrogging technologies
and the fact that there is a true, phenomenal,

3356.54.text:
wonderful, powerful information revolution
underway of which we’re just in the early

3364.40.text:
stages. We’re still on the first slope of
the S-curve in that, and that’s great.

3371.73.text:
But, there are huge headwinds of which I would
say demography and climate change are two,

3378.49.text:
plus the traditional facts for a lot of Africa:
disease, very difficult tropical environment,

3387.82.text:
and 14 landlocked countries, all of which
make this a very special problem.

3395.35.text:
TYLER COWEN: Let me give you another Dani
Rodrik argument. He says that once countries

3399.29.text:
get a foothold in manufacturing, their productivity
levels converge pretty quickly, but in agriculture

3405.01.text:
it’s much longer. You’ve probably looked
at those same numbers. It at least seems true

3408.98.text:
to me. Do you agree with this, and do you
think it’s a major problem facing Africa?

3414.71.text:
If so, what should they do about it?
JEFFREY SACHS: It’s an example of the ecological

3425.94.text:
context and geography being important. The
reason you can get manufacturing convergence

3433.01.text:
of productivity easily is that those are standardized
technologies, usually part of international

3439.60.text:
value chains. The specs, equipment, and machinery
don’t come domestically. They come internationally.

3449.25.text:
The procedures, everything about the production
systems, are basically part of an international

3454.71.text:
system.
When it comes to agriculture, you’re in

3457.30.text:
a completely different world. What counts
is your soil, your pests, your climate conditions,

3464.17.text:
your crop varieties locally. That’s why
technological diffusion in agriculture is

3470.46.text:
much more complex. You cannot simply take,
most of the time, something that worked here

3478.20.text:
and plant it here.
The double miracle of the Indian Green Revolution

3486.05.text:
was actually two miracles. One was that crop
yields went up quickly—but, second, that

3492.32.text:
they were from seeds from Sonora, Mexico,
that Norman Borlaug had taken to India. Lo

3497.91.text:
and behold, after one year of a little bit
of experimentation on how to plant them, he

3503.22.text:
and M. S. Swaminathan found that you could
use Mexican seeds in the Indian context in

3509.42.text:
the Punjab.
The point that Rodrik may be emphasizing here,

3515.31.text:
or finding implicitly, is that technologies
diffuse at different rates depending on their

3522.05.text:
capacity for standardization.
Manufacturing is typically a very standardized

3529.02.text:
global process. You can make the phones. If
you’re making the phones, you’re making

3533.94.text:
the same phones whether it’s in Thailand,
in China, in Foxconn wherever it is it. Whereas

3538.95.text:
if you’re controlling disease, your disease
burdens are different, your ecology is different.

3544.27.text:
If you’re growing food, it’s different.
Therefore the context is much more complex.

3548.24.text:
TYLER COWEN: Of all the wonderful music in
Africa, you must have heard a lot of it. What’s

3554.88.text:
TYLER COWEN: Drums? From which part?
JEFFREY SACHS: Of course, everywhere. It’s

3559.31.text:
beautiful. Basically it’s a truism and obvious,
but how much of American music is African

3564.71.text:
music? We live on a culture that came from
Africa, through the Caribbean, to jazz, to

3576.04.text:
so much. When you watch African music you
see so much of the heritage, roots, and improvements

3585.81.text:
of culture and music that you see here.
TYLER COWEN: From all countries, what’s

3591.55.text:
your favorite novel? Which novel has influenced
you the most? How has it shaped your thinking?

3596.35.text:
How does it play into the other points we’ve
been discussing? Peter Thiel said Lord of

3602.84.text:
the Rings and Master and Margarita.
JEFFREY SACHS: I’m a complete sucker for

3606.66.text:
Doctor Zhivago.
TYLER COWEN: Doctor Zhivago?

3608.06.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Absolutely.
TYLER COWEN: What does it show about Russians

3611.25.text:
and their future?
JEFFREY SACHS: I love the basic idea that

3617.02.text:
in the midst of this revolution Zhivago said,
“Somebody has to just live.” It’s the

3624.04.text:
most human, wonderful story. I am a complete
sucker for it.

3629.21.text:
TYLER COWEN: China and Chinese demography,
what will happen with China now, and what

3633.89.text:
do they need to do?
JEFFREY SACHS: What’s happened of fundamental

3639.66.text:
significance for the world is that East Asia
has become the third growth pole in the world,

3645.80.text:
or arguably the second, because for the first
200 years of modern economic growth, it was

3652.03.text:
all the North Atlantic.
You could call that two regions or one depending

3656.43.text:
on how you want to define it, but it was the
US and Europe that defined 90 percent of the

3663.01.text:
technological advance that created the underlying
dynamics to which the whole rest of the world

3669.65.text:
would engage in catching up, integration,
or falling under imperial rule, or whatever

3675.48.text:
it was.
Now, because of the long history of Japanese

3683.52.text:
development, because of the 50-year history
of Korean and Taiwanese, Hong Kong, Singapore

3691.68.text:
development, and especially because of the
post-1978 scale of China’s achievement,

3698.33.text:
East Asia is an absolutely key, transformative
growth pole of the world. This, I think, is

3710.32.text:
a fundamental geopolitical, historical, and
economic significance.

3714.05.text:
TYLER COWEN: But is China crashing now? There’s
a real estate bubble, a lot of provincial

3719.55.text:
debt, funny numbers, excess capacity. What’s
your take?

3721.87.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: My take is that China will
be a great and successful country in the 21st

3726.99.text:
century.
TYLER COWEN: [Lawrence] Summers and Lant Pritchett

3729.26.text:
say China will slow down and grow at 4 percent
if they’re lucky. Do you agree?

3733.27.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Summers and Lant Pritchett
have been wrong about China for 20 years.

3738.31.text:
[laughter]
JEFFREY SACHS: And they continue to be. And

3742.77.text:
Krugman, too. There was this feeling in Cambridge,
for some reason, 25 years ago, “We don’t

3749.19.text:
like East Asia too much.” I’m caricaturing
just a little bit. China is a bubble. “The

3756.05.text:
Myth of the East Asian Miracle,” remember
Krugman’s article and so forth?

3762.09.text:
They just got it wrong time and again. They
had failed to understand, and the same with

3767.32.text:
Acemoglu. It’s the same story. It doesn’t
fit our model exactly, so it can’t happen.

3773.18.text:
It’s got to collapse. That’s not right.
It’s happening. That’s the story of our

3779.24.text:
time. It’s happening.
One and a half billion, two billion people

3786.17.text:
including other parts of Southeast Asia—they’re
on an upswing. That’s great. It’s wonderful.

3794.22.text:
It’s the most significant scaled improvement
of material conditions in the history of the

3799.70.text:
world in a short period of time. It’s deep.
It’s great civilizations, great cultures,

3806.33.text:
great capacity.
TYLER COWEN: You think they’ll keep growing

3810.05.text:
at 7 percent or not too far from that number?
JEFFREY SACHS: I think that the general idea

3815.77.text:
of Robert Barro [and Xavier Sala-i-Martin]
from 20 years ago that every time you approach

3822.48.text:
by half the way to the frontier you lose about
two percentage points of growth is about right.

3829.77.text:
TYLER COWEN: And will apply to them?
JEFFREY SACHS: Of course.

3832.15.text:
TYLER COWEN: What’s your biggest disagreement
with Krugman today?

3837.93.text:
TYLER COWEN: Please tell us more.
JEFFREY SACHS: He wrote a ridiculous column

3845.26.text:
yesterday.
TYLER COWEN: What do you disagree with?

3849.61.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: It’s an interesting story.
Yesterday he wrote about how horrible the

3855.99.text:
UK government has been and how they’re going
to possibly win an election by telling the

3862.25.text:
story that they’ve done a decent job economically.
He’s had a kind of venom for the government.

3867.50.text:
My response, which I’ll publish soon, is
called something like “Krugman’s Anti-Cameron

3877.70.text:
Vitriol,” because it really is vitriolic.
What I did was just put the UK recovery next

3885.48.text:
to the US recovery, and they look almost identical.
He loves the Obama recovery, and he hates

3890.63.text:
the UK. He says one’s awful, one’s great.
It’s ideology. It’s not fact-driven.

3896.76.text:
TYLER COWEN: You’re more skeptical about
fiscal stimulus than he is, right?

3901.47.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: He has told his readers two
times a week for five years the simplest version

3911.05.text:
of the crudest Keynesian model, which is the
way out of a downturn is fiscal stimulus.

3920.89.text:
I worked on macroeconomic adjustment programs
in dozens of countries for 35 years. I don’t

3929.03.text:
buy it. I think he really took a complicated
subject and said, “There’s one answer,

3937.23.text:
and it comes back to the same approach.”
TYLER COWEN: Preferential diagnostics.

3940.65.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Yeah, and basically, by the
way, he did, in my view, two things wrong.

3945.69.text:
He misdiagnosed the 2008 crisis, and second,
then, gave the prescription to it. The misdiagnosis,

3954.14.text:
in my view, is it was not a Keynesian animal
spirit’s crisis, meaning that suddenly there

3961.66.text:
was just a collapse of investment and you
needed fiscal stimulus to undo it.

3968.47.text:
It was two things, I would say. If you want
to classify it, it was a Hayekian displacement

3980.85.text:
from a credit boom, but even that wasn’t
enough to lead to a crisis. It was Lehman

3989.26.text:
Brothers failing in September 14, 2008, that
drove a financial panic. Addressing a financial

3995.19.text:
panic is a condition that needs to be addressed
as its own pathology.

4005.77.text:
That’s my view that if you approached it
that way—because I remember arguing with

4012.16.text:
Summers that weekend, and many weekends after
that—approach it as unlocking the financial

4020.62.text:
panic, not as the need for reaching a $1.6
trillion deficit in 2009. Just get credit

4029.35.text:
going again.
In that case, I think, Bernanke, by the way,

4033.45.text:
did the right thing, which was flood the market
with liquidity, make extraordinary purchases,

4039.37.text:
QE, all the rest. I thought it was the right
policy in 2008 to ’09, not the fiscal stimulus,

4048.65.text:
because I didn’t think it would work. I
didn’t think it was necessary.

4051.17.text:
I thought it would lead to a big diversion
of attention and public investment actually

4058.40.text:
from longer-term things, which in a way is
how I would interpret our recent political

4064.50.text:
history. In other words, Obama used his political
capital for the wrong thing in that fiscal

4071.77.text:
stimulus.
In any event, I have disagreed with Krugman

4075.35.text:
all through these years about this. He kept
saying, “We’re in a depression. We’re

4080.04.text:
in a depression.” Then when we started to
recover I said, “Oh, we’re recovering.”

4085.75.text:
“No, no, we’re still in a depression.”
Then when we really recovered he said, “Just

4091.40.text:
as I said. We recovered because we had this
2009 stimulus.” We recovered in the context

4100.00.text:
of a significant fiscal cut, actually, not
what he recommended because fiscal policy

4106.36.text:
wasn’t the decisive element of this business
cycle.

4109.61.text:
TYLER COWEN: We have about five minutes left.
I’ll give you two questions, and you can

4113.27.text:
divvy up the time for them as you wish. First
is to tell us a bit about your new work on

4117.98.text:
“rise of the robots.” Also, do you view
this as a description of what’s happening

4122.55.text:
already or a prediction for the future? Second,
tell us how to fix graduate education in economics.

4129.74.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Good.
TYLER COWEN: We’ll also learn something

4133.20.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: OK. So, robots.
TYLER COWEN: It may be the same answer for

4139.52.text:
TYLER COWEN: Robot professors.
JEFFREY SACHS: Very quick. Yeah, robots could

4143.69.text:
teach our classes too. Very quick on robots,
fascinating. I’m a technophile and a techno-believer.

4154.80.text:
I do believe that we are in a very rapid ascent
of information technology.

4161.75.text:
I believe that it is displacing lots of jobs
and it is one of the reasons for the low wages,

4168.47.text:
the stagnation of real earnings in the economy
because the path of manufacturing employment,

4175.48.text:
which we talked about, has shrunk considerably,
chronically.

4181.42.text:
More will come. It will also spread through
the service economy as well. You don’t need

4190.63.text:
baristas in Starbucks. We will walk in, soon,
to a Starbucks, and our iris will be scanned.

4200.24.text:
Your default mode of a mocha latte venti will
come out automatically of a machine. You’ll

4207.02.text:
take it out the other door.
TYLER COWEN: They’ll predict which days

4210.42.text:
you’re going to come, even, right?
JEFFREY SACHS: Pardon me?

4212.93.text:
TYLER COWEN: They’ll predict which days
you’re going to come.

4215.21.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Yeah, they’ll have a very
good idea. They’ll welcome you by name,

4218.08.text:
of course, as you arrive. “Oh, we were expecting
you. You’re 10 minutes late. Is everything

4224.66.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Because Google will know where
you are any moment anyway. That’s coming,

4232.81.text:
and it will transform, fundamentally, the
labor market. The interesting conceptual question

4239.37.text:
is, “Is this a good thing or a bad thing?”
As economists we should say instinctively,

4246.45.text:
“It’s a great thing. Are you kidding?
We can have the robots do all the work for

4251.49.text:
us,” and I believe that’s what we’ve
hoped for ever since leaving Eden when we

4256.49.text:
were condemned to work in the fields 10,000
years ago in the Neolithic Revolution. We’ve

4261.76.text:
been trying to escape heavy labor. If the
robots will do it, fantastic.

4267.46.text:
But there is this, actually, deep conceptual
question. There is something right, actually,

4276.79.text:
theoretically about the argument that the
demand for labor falls, the wages decline,

4284.23.text:
and that can actually lead to a downward spiral
in our economies.

4291.15.text:
I have a paper from last year with Larry Kotlikoff
showing how that works. I have another paper

4297.58.text:
coming out in a couple of weeks that I really
like showing, in an overlapping generations

4303.74.text:
context, how you can get weird outcomes.
But what’s always true is that, with enough

4310.38.text:
government intervention, redistribution of
various kinds from old to young, for example,

4316.92.text:
from capital owners to labor owners, of course
you can make everybody better off—because

4322.82.text:
pure technological change by definition, if
properly handled, can make everybody better

4329.99.text:
off.
This question of how we’re going to handle

4334.17.text:
this transition is a really interesting one.
I believe it’s happening. I believe it’s

4340.70.text:
a fascinating subject for analysis and research.
I believe it’s not been studied in very

4347.71.text:
much depth yet. That leads me to the second
question, because it is a good segue. What

4353.98.text:
do we learn in economics? I believe not the
right things. I’ll take just this question.

4363.48.text:
In my view, whether it’s the geography questions
or the manufacturing question that you asked

4371.21.text:
about or the robotics or whatever it is, what’s
fascinating for us in our real lives and in

4382.02.text:
our societal choices is the change that we’re
constantly living in during this past 230

4391.24.text:
years since Watt gave us the steam engine.
We’ve been in 230 years of relentless change;

4399.14.text:
technological change, structural change, societal
change, cultural change.

4405.72.text:
Yet our economics models are basically static,
meant to be timeless. If we really want to

4415.57.text:
understand the world, we need to go deep into
understanding what Baxter is doing—Baxter

4422.97.text:
the Robot—or Watson, or what really is changing
technologically.

4428.32.text:
TYLER COWEN: Concretely, at the graduate level,
what would you do with them?

4432.35.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Economics. We avoid that, I
think, conceptually, because if you study

4439.90.text:
anything too specific it’s out of date in
10 years. So we study general principles.

4447.42.text:
I think that’s epistemologically the weakness
of our field. We want to be the four underlying,

4456.37.text:
natural forces of the social universe rather
than studying specifics.

4461.66.text:
TYLER COWEN: More like the anthropologists.
JEFFREY SACHS: No, more like the biologists.

4467.17.text:
If Watson and Crick had written their 1953
paper saying, “Assume n base pairs.” They

4476.96.text:
can match by [n × (n − 1)] / 2 combinations.
It wouldn’t be a very good model of DNA.

4484.80.text:
They actually said there are four base pairs,
and there are two natural matchings. It happens

4490.36.text:
to be a double helix.
We’re going to study the detail out of that

4495.55.text:
for the next 40 years. Yeah, it’s arbitrary.
There could be other DNA, but we’re going

4502.15.text:
to study this one. Economists don’t do that,
because we have a harder job, in some sense,

4509.77.text:
which is that we’re not studying a stable
environment. We’re studying a changing environment.

4517.03.text:
Whatever we study in depth will be out of
date. We’re looking at a moving target.

4523.97.text:
To compensate for that by never getting into
detail has been our approach, but we’re

4531.05.text:
always behind the curve, then. We never have
good answers when they’re needed. That’s

4539.30.text:
what I would like us to study.
I would like economists to be working with

4543.75.text:
engineers, to be working with public health,
to be working with the medical professionals

4551.38.text:
so that we’re actually working on the real
systems of our time and adding our pieces

4558.84.text:
to that, understanding and studying that so
that we have an answer to robotics, not a

4564.02.text:
pure theoretical model, which is nice and
fun, but something that can be helpful.

4570.15.text:
TYLER COWEN: On that, we will close the formal
discussion. Thank you, Jeff.

4579.18.text:
AUDIENCE MEMBER: Should I introduce myself
first?

4585.40.text:
TYLER COWEN: Sure.
AUDIENCE MEMBER: My name is Milette Daniel,

4594.28.text:
and I’m currently in the master’s program
for international commerce and policy. My

4617.54.text:
question is regarding robotics, potentially—or
futuristically speaking—taking over what

4630.04.text:
would be the low-skill jobs at first. What
do you think the implications would be on

4635.02.text:
immigration?
JEFFREY SACHS: The affect on . . . ?

4637.82.text:
AUDIENCE MEMBER: On immigration, due to the
changing labor market.

4642.72.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Yes, the robots are a kind
of immigrant, so they’re competing with

4648.93.text:
the other workers that provide some services
that are being replaced by the machines or

4661.86.text:
by the artificial intelligence systems. There
is a big distributional effect, in my view.

4669.38.text:
Those who own the robots, as it were, whether
it’s Larry Page and Sergey Brin or others,

4676.07.text:
make a fortune. And those who own the labor
that is being substituted see a real decline

4687.46.text:
of their income.
Again, conceptually, the idea that machines

4694.14.text:
could do the heavy lifting for us is a good
thing for society. I don’t know if it’s

4702.57.text:
a real insight or not, but I went to Virunga
National Park in Rwanda [sic] a couple of

4711.57.text:
years ago to visit the great apes, the gorillas.
You spend this remarkable time in the bamboo

4720.13.text:
forest watching them. What do they do all
day? They play. They lie around. They eat

4728.88.text:
some bamboo shoots. A little sex now and then.
Basically, it’s a pretty leisurely existence.

4737.69.text:
We’re told, by anthropologists, that that’s
not so much unlike hunter-gatherer societies

4746.05.text:
in the pre-Neolithic.
We got into a different mode about 10,000

4753.30.text:
years ago. Became sedentary. Human populations
rose. For the next 10,000 years, people broke

4761.88.text:
their backs trying to stay alive growing food.
We got into a kind of mode where, basically,

4769.67.text:
very, very, very hard labor. The big quest
of modern times is to get out of that hard,

4778.88.text:
heavy physical labor. That’s what everyone
in the world wants.

4783.32.text:
As soon as you can get out of agriculture,
people do. That’s why we’re down to 1

4787.45.text:
percent of our labor force in agriculture.
It’s very hard work. When you watch people

4794.00.text:
bent over for eight hours in the fields in
Africa today, it’s no joy for their lives.

4800.10.text:
It’s extraordinarily difficult.
I say all of this because what machines do,

4806.52.text:
what smart machines have been doing for 200
years, is allowing us to ease that physical

4813.38.text:
burden. We’ve had robots for a long time
now. They’re just getting smarter and smarter

4820.22.text:
because they have microprocessors now and
artificial intelligence. They’re allowing

4825.90.text:
humanity to escape from a very heavy load.
On principle, this is a nice thing. This is

4834.13.text:
where we would like to go. If it leads to
turmoil, massive inequalities of power and

4842.41.text:
income and wealth, or, by the way, the other
dystopian possibilities, which George Orwell

4854.08.text:
depicted. We already have a mass surveillance
state in this country, probably not too far

4860.07.text:
from here. I hope they’re listening.
I expect every time I pick up the phone—I

4866.93.text:
used to say, “Hello, NSA, I know you’re
listening.” Then I was told it’s probably

4872.97.text:
six intelligence agencies listening. All I’m
saying is, like all the things we discussed,

4881.86.text:
I believe that artificial intelligence robotics
is real, deep, transformative, potentially
